## Aim

To determine whether the timing of external-beam radiotherapy affected the number of wound healing complications in soft-tissue sarcoma in the limbs of adults.

## Outcome measures

- Primary endpoint was the rate of wound complications within 120 days of surgery, defined as:

- Secondary surgery
- Hospital admission for wound care (e.g. for IV abx)
- Need for deep packing or prolonged wound dressings for >120 days

## Results

- Study terminated for a highly significant result at planned interim analysis
- At a median follow-up of 3.3 years, acute wound complications significantly more common with pre-op DXT treatment (35% v 17%)
- Poor prognostic factors:
    - Higher volume resected tissue
    - Lower limb tumours

## Longer-term results

- No difference in local control with pre- versus post- DXT (at median 6.9 years)
- ~90% local control
- Similar progression-free and overall survival
- Post-op DXT associated to higher grade 2 to 4 late toxicity (86% v 68%).
- Grade 3-4 significantly higher in post-op (36% v 23%)

## What is a radiation-associated sarcoma? {.smaller .scrollable}

- Contrast with *sporadic* sarcoma
- Cahan criteria

  - Radiation given previously; sarcoma arising in the area included within the 5 percent isodose line.
  - Histologic features of original lesion and post-radiation sarcoma different.
  - Patients with inherited syndromes that predispose to sarcomas should be excluded.
  - Minimal latency period (between initiation of DXT initiation and diagnosis of second tumour) >5 years*

*Controversial - may be as little as 6 months

## TAKE HOME 1: When is DXT not needed? {.smaller}

Surgical excision alone for:

- Superficial tumours
- Low-grade tumours <5cm in diameter
- Intramuscular tumours that can be resected with wide margin and still preserve function

## TAKE HOME 2: Pre-op DXT {.smaller}

::: columns
::: {.column width="45%"}
### Advantages
- Lower dose (50 Gy) to a smaller target volume (compared to 50 Gy plus 16 to 20 Gy boost)
- May reduce tumour burden and allow more conservative surgery
- Upper limb > Lower limb
:::

::: {.column width="10%"}
:::

::: {.column width="45%"}
### Disadvantages
- Histological examination of specimen less useful
- Higher rate of wound complications
:::
:::
